channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Wants Fealty, and He’s Found It in Africa
item.description: The Russian president has unleashed a new disorder on the world with his war in Ukraine, and the Central African Republic may be its ultimate expression.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Russian soldiers protecting civilians in central Bangui.

item.title: Lonely, Single and Over 50? China Has a Game Show for That.
item.description: Several popular television programs in the country are helping to encourage conversations about the social, romantic and sexual needs of older Chinese people.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong

item.title: At Least 7 Killed in Kherson Shelling, Fueling Anger Over Christmas Strikes
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine had urged vigilance after the military noted the presence of Russian ships carrying cruise missiles in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A man injured in the attack on Saturday. The streets of Kherson were busy on Saturday morning when Russian forces shelled the city center, according to an aide to the Ukrainian president.

item.title: A Christmas Tree Brings Life to a Destroyed Palestinian Village
item.description: For former residents of Iqrit, where Israeli forces leveled everything but the church in 1951, religious rituals bind them to a place from which they were expelled.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families gathering for the tree lighting in the Palestinian Christian village of Iqrit, Israel, this month.

item.title: As Cases Explode, China’s Low Covid Death Toll Convinces No One
item.description: China’s murky statistics are fueling widespread public distrust. Its narrow definition of Covid deaths “will very much underestimate the true death toll,” the W.H.O. says.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Workers moving a body to a container for storage at a crematory in Beijing. Reports of people dying after contracting Covid have soared in the two weeks since China abruptly abandoned Covid restrictions.

item.title: At German Christmas Markets, Smiles Shine Bright but Budgets Are Tight
item.description: In Nuremberg, the stalls are open without Covid restrictions, and big crowds are returning to sip mulled wine and socialize. But amid economic uncertainty, visitors are spending less.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Few places in Germany feel as Christmassy at this time of year as the Nuremberg Christkindlesmarkt, one of the oldest and most storied festive markets in the country.

item.title: His Job Description? Protecting German Democracy. Literally.
item.description: Thomas Haldenwang runs Germany’s Office for the Protection of the Constitution. His mission is to fight the enemies of German democracy — from far-right coup plotters to Russian hackers.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Haldenwang, Germany’s domestic intelligence chief, at Hambach Castle in Neustadt, Germany.

item.title: Tracking North Korea’s Record Number of Missile Launches
item.description: Kim Jong-un’s regime has launched more than 90 ballistic and other missiles in 2022 — more than in any previous year — in defiance of United Nations resolutions.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Television screens in Seoul showing a news report in November airing file footage on a North Korean missile launch.

item.title: Paris Shooting: At Least 3 Killed in Suspected Racist Attack
item.description: The shooting, which prompted protests, took place at a Kurdish community center, and a 69-year-old has been taken into custody. The authorities said he “clearly wanted to target foreigners.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Members of Kurdish community clashed with police officers in the area where the shooting took place.

item.title: As Hope Fades for Missing Thai Sailors, Ship’s Safety Is Scrutinized
item.description: Five days after the warship sank, 23 men remain missing. The authorities said the warship did not have enough life jackets.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A rescued sailor from the HTMS Sukhothai being transferred to land at Bang Saphan Port in Prachuap Khiri Khan Province, Thailand, on Monday.

item.title: Israel’s New Government Pushes A Rush of Far-Right Initiatives
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu needed the support of far-right factions to return to the prime minister’s office. Now they want to curb the powers of the judiciary, giving rise to fears about an erosion of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister designate, is preparing to swear in his new right-wing government.

item.title: At France’s Oldest Christmas Market, Energy Crisis Dims Festive Spirits
item.description: Amid soaring gas prices and the war in Ukraine, Strasbourg’s Christkindelsmärik, like holiday fairs across Europe, has faced a tough question: “How do you balance magic and responsibility?”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: How Does Pompeii Maintain Its Ruins? Hungry Sheep.
item.description: The archaeological park of Pompeii has found a low-tech way to prevent the site from being overrun by vegetation: hungry sheep.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaspare de Martino grazing his sheep in an unexcavated section of the Pompeii archaeological site.

item.title: Your Favorite Things of 2022
item.description: This week, your best highly specific best-ofs of the year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Syrian Family That Rebuilt a Chocolate Empire in Nova Scotia
item.description: Seven years on, Peace by Chocolate continues to expand, and its founder has become an advocate of more open immigration.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Tareq Hadhad, a medical student in Syria, became known in Canada for restarting a family chocolate business.

item.title: What Are JDAMs? And What Will They Do For Ukraine?
item.description: The United States is giving satellite-guided bombs to Kyiv for the first time as part of a new $1.85 billion military aid package.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: South Korean Defense Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A South Korean fighter jet dropping two Joint Direct Attack Munitions in October.

item.title: Threat of Invasion From Belarus Low, Says Ukraine Spy Chief
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview on the state of the war, Kyrylo Budanov also spoke about Russia-Iran relations and Moscow’s obsession with taking the city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian mechanized infantry brigade near the front lines in the Donbas region on Thursday.

item.title: Russian Forces Shell Ukraine’s Kherson Region
item.description: At least five civilians were killed and 18 injured in Russian attacks on Thursday and into Friday morning, an official said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian attacks continued in Ukraine, with at least five civilians killed on Thursday and early Friday.

item.title: What Is a ‘Bomb Cyclone’?
item.description: These storms aren’t tremendously rare, but this particular one is much more powerful than most.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Joseph Cress/Iowa City Press-Citizen, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Icy conditions in North Liberty, Iowa, on Thursday.

item.title: A Brutal Storm
item.description: Just before Christmas, a combination of ice, snow and winds is paralyzing much of the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow and wind in Chicago yesterday.

item.title: Iran condemns Zelensky’s remarks to Congress as ‘baseless.’
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: An Iranian-made Shahed-136 drone over Kyiv in October during a Russian attack.

item.title: How to Travel the World While Putting Nature First
item.description: In the wake of the U.N. biodiversity conference, Julia Simpson, the head of the World Travel and Tourism Council, discusses a new initiative called nature positive travel.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: “We used to talk about leaving a lighter footprint,” said Julia Simpson (above), the president and chief executive of the World Travel and Tourism Council. “But now I think people actually want to have a positive footprint.”

item.title: The Senate passes a spending bill that includes nearly $50 billion in aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: The 4,155-page bill funds the U.S. government through September and substantially increases spending.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky’s return to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky is greeted in the House chambers after he addressed a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Day 23: On Christmas Day, No Rest for the Weary. (Or the Guy Who Feeds the Penguins.)
item.description: For a biologist in San Francisco, Dec. 25 will bring not presents and mistletoe, but beak trims and fish guts.
item.dc:creator: Chris Colin
item.media:credit: LeeAndra Cianci, Photo by Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: San Francisco biologist Sparks Perkins works on Christmas to tend to the needs of the resident penguins at the California Academy of Sciences’s Steinhart Aquarium. He holds an African penguin chick. New swimming feathers, stiffer and sleek, are replacing the chick’s fuzzy baby down.

item.title: Congress Votes to Expand U.S. Power to Prosecute International War Crimes
item.description: Passed after an address by Ukraine’s leader, the bill would allow foreigners in the United States who are suspected of war crimes to be tried even if the crime was overseas and the victim was not American.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Perpetrators committing unspeakable war crimes, such as those unfolding before our very eyes in Ukraine, must be held to account,” said Senator Richard J. Durbin, left, who helped shepherd the bill.

item.title: Zelensky’s Welcome in Washington Buoys Morale in Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainians, many left in the dark and cold by Russian airstrikes, drew solace from President Volodymyr Zelensky’s speech to Congress.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky received a standing ovation from many members of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky’s Weapons Wish List Goes Mostly Unfulfilled on Trip to Washington
item.description: The Biden administration continues to balk at sending U.S. battle tanks, fighter jets and long-range missiles to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed members of Congress on Wednesday, and was candid about his desire for more U.S. military aid.

item.title: Putin says giving Patriot missiles to Kyiv ‘is simply prolonging the conflict.’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Russian state news media, President Vladimir V. Putin at a news conference in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Juan Guaidó, the Face of Opposition in Venezuela, May Be Voted Out
item.description: The lawmaker may soon be voted out of power by the opposition, which no longer sees his interim government as a path to “real political change” against the country’s authoritarian government.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juan Guaidó speaking in Caracas in 2019.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Times Investigation Into Bucha
item.description: Also, Benjamin Netanyahu is poised to lead Israel again and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: White House Says North Korea Is Delivering Arms to Russia’s Wagner Group
item.description: The paramilitary group has played a central role in Russia’s efforts to storm the city of Bakhmut in Donetsk Province, which borders Luhansk.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: The entrance to the PMC Wagner Center, associated with the founder of the private Wagner Group, in St. Petersburg, Russia, last month.

item.title: Xi Xi, Whose Writing Defined a Changing Hong Kong, Dies at 85
item.description: Her work captured the unease of Hong Kong’s transition to Chinese rule, gave voice to the city’s children and working-class residents, and helped put it on the literary map.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: The author Xi Xi at her home in Hong Kong with one of the teddy bears she started making as physical therapy after cancer treatment, dressing them as figures from Chinese mythology, literature and history.

item.title: Germany Arrests a Suspected Russian Spy Inside Its Intelligence Agency
item.description: The suspect, a German citizen, is being charged with treason. He is accused of passing state secrets to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon

item.title: Oscar White Muscarella, Museum ‘Voice of Conscience,’ Dies at 91
item.description: An archaeologist at the Met, he warned about plundered and fake antiquities and about the acquisition practices of collectors and museums, including his own.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Lukashenko Speaks on Belarus’s Military Moves and Ukraine War
item.description: Some Ukrainian officials have warned that a military exercise involving Russia could be a precursor to a new offensive aimed at Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus during a joint military exercise with Russian forces a week before Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine in February.

item.title: Waiter Shortage Hits London Restaurants After Brexit
item.description: Europeans used to flock to London for restaurant jobs. Now, with doors to migrants largely closed after Britain left the European Union, many establishments are becoming desperate.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Padella, in Shoreditch, East London. Restaurants across London are so short of staff that many have curtailed their hours.

item.title: Zelensky Brings His Olive Green Sweatshirt to Congress
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine came to Washington wearing his reality on his sleeves.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Speaker Nancy Pelosi holding a Ukrainian flag signed by members of that country’s military. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine presented the flag to them when he addressed Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: In Bakhmut, a Food Stand Stays Open Despite the War
item.description: Despite all the shelling, and with no electricity, one snack shop is still serving the soldiers and citizens who have stayed in Bakhmut, Ukraine, a pivotal battleground in the war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Trump Oversight
item.description: After years of evading congressional investigators, Donald Trump is taking hits.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump.

item.title: For Zelensky, a Celebration of Resilience and a Sales Pitch for Support
item.description: For all the talk of victory, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s remarks in Washington revealed hints about his worries for the year ahead.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky receiving a standing ovation as he addressed the U.S. Congress in a joint session at the Capitol in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is the Polar Vortex? And Other Cold-Weather Climate Questions
item.description: As much of the United States plunges into a deep freeze, scientists continue to debate how rapid Arctic warming is playing a role.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Source: Climate Reanalyzer, Climate Change Institute at the University of Maine, using forecasts from the National Centers for Environmental Prediction Global Forecast System.

item.title: Nepali Court Orders the Release of Charles Sobhraj From Prison
item.description: The action trims the life sentence Charles Sobhraj, known as ‘the Serpent,’ who targeted Western tourists in Asia in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Charles Sobhraj, a French killer known as “the Serpent,” arriving for a court hearing in Bhaktapur, Nepal, in 2014.

item.title: Caught on Camera, Traced by Phone: The Russian Military Unit That Killed Dozens in Bucha
item.description: Exclusive evidence obtained in a monthslong investigation identifies the Russian regiment — and commander — behind one of the worst atrocities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Dmitriy Khavin, Christoph Koettl, Haley Willis, Alexander Cardia, Natalie Reneau and Malachy Browne
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Ukrainian leader sought to convey the reality of the war to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Bakhmut, the site of one of the bloodiest campaigns of the war, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky visited President Biden in his first known trip outside Ukraine since Russia invaded.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi hoist a Ukrainian flag signed by soldiers in the midst of war as Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky addresses a joint session of Congress.

item.title: Day 22: A Very Bollywood Christmas Playlist
item.description: Like many families only one generation removed from the “old country,” an Indian American writer’s family puts its own imprint on this omnipresent holiday.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Yasmin Marikar

item.title: Biden and Zelensky Present a United Front Against Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky described military assistance for Ukraine as an investment in global security and democracy in the face of Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Speaker Nancy Pelosi hold a Ukrainian flag signed by soldiers on the front line, delivered by President Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Zelensky’s Message: Ukraine Is Fighting for Good Over Evil
item.description: One of the Ukrainian leader’s overriding aims is to prevent support for the war from becoming a partisan issue.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Concedes Military Failings, but Insists Russia Will Fight On
item.description: Nodding to criticism that his army lacked the basic necessities to wage war, the Russian leader said his government was providing “everything that the army asks for.’’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu, left, on Wednesday said, “The country and the government are providing everything that the army asks for — everything.”

item.title: Coalition Deal Puts Netanyahu on Brink of Power in Israel
item.description: After weeks of talks, Benjamin Netanyahu said he had formed a new governing coalition. Once ratified by Parliament, the deal will return him to power at the head of a hard-right alliance.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, has succeeded in forming a coalition government that is set to bring him back to power at the helm of the most right-wing administration in Israeli history.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Zelensky at the White House
item.description: Also, Donald Trump’s tax returns show losses during his presidency.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky went to Washington after visiting Ukraine’s eastern front.

item.title: President López Obrador Suggests the Attack on Ciro Gómez Leyva Was Staged
item.description: After assailants shot at Ciro Gómez Leyva in his own neighborhood, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador suggested that the assassination attempt was actually an effort to destabilize the government.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Germán Espinosa/Agencia EL UNIVERSAL/GDA via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ciro Gómez Leyva, a leading Mexican news anchor, was attacked by gunmen last week while driving through his neighborhood.

item.title: What Are Patriot Missiles, and Why Does Ukraine Want Them?
item.description: The United States is sending its most advanced ground-based missile defense system to Ukraine, as Russia continues to pummel the country with airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Patriot antimissile system launcher in Rzeszow, Poland, in March.

item.title: As Ukraine Prepares for a Second Year at War, the Prospect of a Stalemate Looms
item.description: American officials believe that with Russia bolstering defenses and learning lessons, Ukraine will find it more challenging to retake land.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military has been reliant on American intelligence reports that pinpoint where the Russian Army is at its weakest.

item.title: 8 Teenage Girls Charged With Fatally Stabbing a Toronto Man
item.description: The police said the girls, who ranged from 13 to 16 years old, connected on social media before meeting up, possibly for the first time, on the day of the killing.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The corner of York St. and University Ave. in downtown Toronto, where the police said 8 teenage girls killed a man on Sunday.

item.title: Putin Vows ‘No Limits’ to Russia’s War Spending
item.description: The Russian leader’s speech to defense officials was his latest effort to show he has no intention of giving up in the war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: At a gathering of senior military officials, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia approved an increase of more than 300,000 troops for the country’s armed forces.

item.title: Hospitalizing the Homeless
item.description: New York City’s struggle to get severely mentally ill people off the streets.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: An encampment in Brooklyn this year.

item.title: UK Ambulance Workers Stage Their Largest Strike in Decades
item.description: The industrial action, seeking higher pay and better working conditions, was driven by a cost-of-living crisis and coincides with strikes by rail workers, nurses and others.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ambulance workers picketing outside the London Ambulance Service, a National Health Service agency, on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Ally Meets With China’s Top Leader, Signaling Close Ties
item.description: China has remained a significant, if largely silent, counterweight to the international censure of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, third from left, met with Dmitri A. Medvedev, the former Russian president and prime minister, center right, in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Electric Cars Are Taking Off, but When Will Battery Recycling Follow?
item.description: Many companies and investors are eager to recycle batteries, but it could take a decade or more before enough used lithium-ion batteries become available.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Reynaga unscrewing the main lithium battery from a vehicle at LKQ’s plant in Adelanto, Calif.
